summary:
I'm a seasoned journalist with over 9 years of experience, specializing in the writing on the intersection of development, environment, sustainability, and the ever-evolving politics of climate change.

My professional journey as a journalist started from business newspapers. Subsequently, I ventured into diverse territories. From webzines to magazines and back to the digital realm, I honed my skills, with hard news as the heart of my profile. This diverse background has equipped me with a deep understanding of the intricacies of journalism across different platforms.

In December 2017, I was inspired by the innovative Swedish movement called Plogging, sparking the birth of my own environmental initiative, Plogga India. Rooted in Delhi (but not limited to) this initiative encourages people to jog with purpose, making a tangible impact against plastic pollution while fostering personal well-being. Plogga India is not merely about cleaning up public spaces; it's about raising awareness of waste's entire lifecycle, from production to disposal. My vision is to instill a mindset of resource efficiency, question rampant consumption, and drive communities towards more sustainable futures. Moreover, we're on a quest to uncover how cities, as hubs of materialism, can slowly but intentionally embrace the principles of the Circular Economy.

As a Master's student of Development Studies at the prestigious International Institute of Social Studies (ISS), The Hague (of Erasmus University Rotterdam), my thesis delved into the realm of grassroots innovations and their connection to place attachment. My research focused on Groene Mient, an inspiring social-ecological intentional collective housing project in The Hague, Netherlands. This exploration shed light on the importance of place attachment in driving grassroots innovations like Groene Mient, with implications for sustainable urban transitions and renewable energy initiatives at the neighborhood level.

In my quest to make a meaningful change, I am actively seeking positions in the Netherlands and the European Union (EU) that align with my expertise and aspirations. Specifically, I am passionate about contributing to policy setting, analysis, and evaluation in areas related to development, environment, and sustainability.

treasury_media.title: Meet The Man Who travelled solo Across 5 Countries to Spread Awareness About 'Plogging'
treasury_media.description: This man went to five different south-east Asian countries to ask people to pick up their plastic trash.

treasury_media.title: Meet Abhimanyu Chakravorty, Who plogged across 5 Countries picking up trash
treasury_media.description: He undertook a solo motorcycle ride through India and travelled to five countries - Myanmar - Thailand- Laos - Cambodia - Nepal - to promote what he had been doing in New Delhi for the past year: plogging, a mix of jogging and picking up trash. This is his way to galvanise individuals and communities to tackle the menace of plastic pollution.

treasury_media.title: Pledging to plog around Asia: Featured in UNEP
treasury_media.description: When Chakravorty, a 31-year-old journalist at the Indian Express, discovered that plastic pollution is so pervasive that it affects our food supply, he was shocked.

treasury_media.title: Southeast Asia talking trash (literally) with West: The Philippines is latest in line
treasury_media.description: Faced with a massive trash problem of their own making, Southeast Asia too is pushing back and increasingly rejecting foreign trash imports fearing they could become the next dumping ground.

treasury_media.title: Nepal’s plastic problem mirrors SE Asian economies’ challenges, but it can change its narrative
treasury_media.description: For decades, low awareness and a near dysfunctional waste management system has resulted in litter either thrown into or dumped on the river banks throughout the valley, which ultimately flows down to the Bagmati river.

treasury_media.title: Laos’ trash problem is an ecological time bomb, here’s how it can course-correct
treasury_media.description: In Laos, newly-empowered consumers are basking in the benefits of the polymer industry without knowing the consequences of their consumption on marine ecosystems.

treasury_media.title: Cambodia is drowning in its waste, here’s how it can plug the plastic flow
treasury_media.description: Just like Thais, Cambodians have a deep-rooted relationship with plastic bags. It’s hard to break up with the clingy habit as it’s a convenience that’s unmatched by any other product.

treasury_media.title: Thailand is addicted to plastic, but here’s how it can kick the habit
treasury_media.description: This story is the second of a four-part series on documenting plastic pollution in Southeast Asia.

treasury_media.title: 5 countries, 13,000 km, 1 goal: Challenge the everyday use of plastic
treasury_media.description: I was on a 3-month bike ride across five countries of Myanmar, Laos, Thailand , Cambodia and Nepal, to challenge the everyday use of plastic through an activity called Plogging - a mix of jogging and picking up trash.

treasury_media.title: Climate change: Water crisis engulfs world’s ‘highest’ village
treasury_media.description: Retreating glaciers and inadequate snowfall during peak winter is threatening the livelihoods and food security of people in Himachal Pradesh’s picturesque Spiti mountain valley.
